timeline.subject: Catherine Jean Claude
timeline.details: First inventory of goods taken, presumably immediately after arrest

timeline.subject: Jean Magnien
timeline.details: List of witnesses prepared by partie formelle Jean Magnien, schoolmaster at Azelot, now imprisoned alongside accused

timeline.subject: Jean Magnien
timeline.details: Magnien interrogated about how he came to be partie formelle

timeline.subject: Gergonne Roussel (maire)
timeline.details: Maire interrogated about Magnien's claims of incitement

timeline.subject: Jean Magnien
timeline.details: Jean Magnien released from prison, under obligation to present himself when required

timeline.subject: Catherine Jean Claude
timeline.details: Second interrogation responding to specific charges

timeline.subject: Catherine Jean Claude
timeline.details: PG de Lorraine (Maimbourg) asks for question extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Catherine Jean Claude
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture - thumbscrews, rack, and tortillons; denied all charges

timeline.subject: Catherine Jean Claude
timeline.details: Formal sentence from Change de Nancy: banishment for 10 years, confiscation of 1/3 goods, payment of costs

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Jean Claude
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle escrioit et appelloit a son ayde ses enfans qui estoient mortz
notable_quotes.english: that she was writing and calling to her aid her children who were dead
notable_quotes.context: When asked what she was doing beating water with a stick at the spring

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengin Regnard (Catherine's words to him)
notable_quotes.french: voyla ton enfant gueris le, tu envoye bien loing au St pour le guerir et il est tout pres
notable_quotes.english: there is your child, cure him, you send very far to the saint to cure him and he is very near
notable_quotes.context: Angry response when another neighbor suggested going on pilgrimage for their sick child

notable_quotes.speaker: maire Gergonne
notable_quotes.context: Referring to Catherine when trying to convince Magnien to be partie formelle

notable_quotes.speaker: wife of Jean Pastel
notable_quotes.french: que malle chartre la puisse enchartrer dans son lict
notable_quotes.english: that evil charter might enchain her in her bed
notable_quotes.context: Curse allegedly wished upon witness by Catherine

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Jean Claude
notable_quotes.french: si elle fut sorciere, elle qui depose s'en fut ressenty
notable_quotes.english: if she were a witch, she who testifies would have felt it
notable_quotes.context: Françoise femme Pierre Bonnet's testimony about their 30+ years of quarrels

notable_quotes.speaker: Belotte femme Jean Marchal
notable_quotes.context: Catherine's statement shortly before arrest while reaping together
notable_quotes.english: She had thought several times of killing herself; had heard that schoolmaster was thinking of having her arrested, and wished it was now. She was willing to suffer in body, provided her soul was saved

relationships.evidence_text: widow of Jean Claude, aged about 82. Husband had died about 12 years earlier

relationships.person1: Marguerite femme Vincenot de la Rue
relationships.evidence_text: Had been married to one of her sons for 11 months
Had been neighbour for many years
Had been her neighbour for 7 years
lived in same house as her

economic_context.details: Catherine owned house (sold for 210 fr), land (161 fr), and household goods (55 fr), total 426 fr. She was also paid for healing services and pilgrimages.

remedy made with rosewater, vinegar, and white of egg for headache

treated animals with salt and onions

residence of multiple witnesses; where bastard child was taken for baptism
residence of maire François Gerard and witness Demenge Jenniot
maire's wife said there was a man from Houdemont who wanted to speak with Catherine
Messire Hilaire was curé of Houdreville
where Odille's son was in service when he developed swollen thigh
where Jean Malherbe lived, who taught Catherine healing prayer when she was young
where Domp Jean de Xanrey lived
pilgrimage site - Catherine's husband had been to St Claude
pilgrimage site recommended for maire's son
where Catherine was found disturbing water; went before dawn on first Friday of May to wash hands
Change de Nancy was the court that tried the case

economic_hardship_indicators: Catherine mentioned 'very dear years' but said she had never been troubled in mind
Jean Magnien described himself as 'a poor man but honest' with wife and 2 children
religious_calendar_references: Whitsun - Magnien had only been at Azelot since previous Whitsun
first Friday of May - when Catherine went to spring for healing ritual
service of the year - mass said a year after someone's death

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jean Pastel threatened to have Catherine arrested for witchcraft
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Catherine said if she were a witch he would have been dead 7 years earlier

legal_context.redress_outcome: Multiple witnesses noted she was called witch publicly but took no legal action for defamation
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: imprisoned alongside Jean Magnien; other prisoners heard noises and cries earlier in week (which Catherine denied)

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Change de Nancy issued final sentence: banishment for 10 years (rather than death), confiscation of 1/3 goods, payment of costs. Court found her 'suffisament attaincte et convaincue' of using charms, enchantments, and illicit means.

hearsay_chains.reporter: Jean Gerard le vieux (from initial list)
hearsay_chains.content: Catherine told her he would die before her
his uncle Laurent Marchal died believing Catherine bewitched him
how he called her witch after drinking, fell ill and died
she had wished 'que malle chartre la puisse enchartrer dans son lict'

hearsay_chains.source: Pierre Bonnet and Domp Jean de Xanrey
hearsay_chains.content: first woman to come into house on return would be cause of children's deaths

emotional_state_notes: said she had thought of drowning herself in her well when she realized people believed her a witch
told Belotte she had thought several times of killing herself
said she wished the schoolmaster would arrest her now, willing to suffer in body if soul saved

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Said that Jean Pastel was cause of his wife's death, because he had beaten her

third_parties.name: Jean Magnien
third_parties.context: schoolmaster at Azelot from Mandre aux quatre tours; imprisoned alongside Catherine; allegedly coerced by maire into becoming partie formelle; later released

third_parties.name: Gergonne Roussel
third_parties.context: allegedly tried to convince multiple people to be partie formelle against Catherine; son Nicolas died during trial

third_parties.name: Nicolas (son of maire)
third_parties.context: married son who died of headache/mental illness; Catherine tried to heal him

third_parties.name: Jean Malherbe
third_parties.context: old man at Fléville who taught Catherine healing prayer when she was young; told her not to use until his death (6 weeks later)

third_parties.name: Esdeline
third_parties.context: old woman of Azelot, now dead, who taught Catherine use of serviette and prayer for animals 40+ years ago

third_parties.name: Jean Pateltangel

third_parties.context: maire allegedly approached him to become partie formelle

third_parties.context: at whose house Magnien dined 2 weeks before arrest

third_parties.name: Messire Hilaire

third_parties.context: mother of bastard child by curé

third_parties.name: Domp Jean de Xanrey
third_parties.context: at Niderhoff; consulted about who stole cloth and made prediction about first woman to enter house

third_parties.name: Gros Claude
third_parties.context: called Catherine witch after drinking, fell ill next day and died

third_parties.name: wife of Jean Doctrinal (sister of Jean Voinchelin)
third_parties.context: died in childbed claiming Catherine responsible after touch on shoulder

third_parties.name: Pierre Bonnet
third_parties.context: tisserand; husband of witness 5; visited Domp Jean de Xanrey about stolen cloth

third_parties.name: 9 children of Catherine
third_parties.context: all 9 children were dead at time of trial

extraction_metadata.notes: Exceptionally detailed trial record with 22 witnesses. Notable for: (1) complex legal drama around partie formelle Jean Magnien being allegedly coerced by maire; (2) Catherine's role as healer/diviner using scarf divination and prayers; (3) survival outcome - banished rather than executed despite torture; (4) extensive testimony about her healing practices being both valued and feared; (5) Catherine's own statements about contemplating suicide due to reputation. Strong evidence of folk healing practices and economic value of her services. Property inventory provides rare economic data.
